ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a very solid understanding of democratic theory and education studies both independently and in play with one another. I now feel comfortable discussing the evolution of our education system and how it has impacted and been impacted by U.S. democratic ideals.

I learned so much about education philosophy. We looked at authors from Plato to Tara Westover and read a lot of news articles and Pew Research papers for current ideas about topics. I learned what it means to think about a text at a deeper level in the philosophy sense instead of just the close-reading sense. I also learned a lot about what a democracy really is beyond a system of govenment.
I developed a better understanding of political theology, as well as improving my paper writing skills.
I learned how to think about the relationship between democracy and education, analyzed historical philosophical texts and modern texts about various aspects of the American Educational system.
Knowledge about various philosopher's/thinker's beliefs on the purpose of education, especially as it relates to a democratic society.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strength: a very intriguing set of texts. I appreciated both the breadth and depth of theory to which the texts introduced us. Class presentations were also an effective and fun way to take ownership of a text and theme.

Strengths: We looked at a ton of different sources, but they were tied together well in most cases. Different viewpoints were compared and contrasted. We gave presentations on a source of our choice, and that was a really good way to dive deeper into a text. 

Weaknesses: I feel like I would have benefitted from direct instruction (either in class or through examples/how-to articles/other resouces) about how to write a philosophy paper. That was the first time I've ever had to write papers like that, and I don't think I really grasped how to do it. Other than that, I think the instructor could have encouraged discourse more. A lot of discussions had us all agreeing with each other. Maybe some mini-debates would have helped us thinnk through the positives of other opinions.

Strengths: Flexibility, kind environment
Weaknesses: Not stimulating,

The class covers a broad range of texts that were interesting to engage with, though were sometimes quite difficult to fully understand. I thought sometimes the seminar structure made it difficult to focus on what aspects were important and relevant.
The course was well organized and pushed us towards a more philosophy-oriented mindset about the use/purpose of education. The course could have been more engaging in discussions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would actually recommend this course to anyone, not just those who are in the humanities and education studies programs. Although the course centered around in-depth discussion and challenging texts, it was easily engaged with even for those who have not had experience in it.

I would recommend it to someone who is familiar with some thoughts about democracy and/or education throughout history, but not someone who has studied it intensely before. I was not familiar with theories about democracy, but I knew some about education through the Foundations in Education Studies course that is required to complete a certificate in Education Studies. If you have already studied these types of theories, I don't know if this is the course for you because we didn't really go super deep into them, just what could be covered in one discussion.
I cautiously would. I think Professor is great, but the course was overall a bit boring and drab.
If you are interested in the intersections of philosophy and education, yes.
